M-ad-fenDEqinu5QFWZE5g.text: Fantastic food. Had the pot stickers, bbq pork, shiitake mushrooms, and the egg rolls along with my beef tenderloin. Everything was perfect. Service and atmosphere are unmatched in Vegas. Eddie the boss and Daniel and Danny are amazing! Definitely recommend!

8h7Dcbvk9rH6ZM5JFl23TQ.text: Good ambience, good service, and a relatively reasonable price. Make sure to ask for their hot sauce if you like spice.

AFYgXdpt0jfHBhTDJYAZjQ.text: The decor... gorgeous.  Best fine dining chinese in vegas. My favorite here is the abalone, and the black pepper foie gras. Yes I said it. BLACK PEPPER FOIE GRAS!!!! Waste no time order it first!

jT40xIEmM6VrpNrxdC2otA.text: The reviews I read on this place don't do it justice. The service was excellent, from the hostess to the server to the people clearing the table. We had the egg rolls and tempura green beans to start; both were delicious but the green beans were out of this world! For dinner we shared Mongolian beef, Kung Pao chicken and vegetable fried rice. All was delicious but the chicken was the BEST!! Would highly recommend!!

OJVmsE8Ixptn5DcCFzaMqw.text: I was quite impressed with the food. Top Asian spot on the strip. Attentive staff, large portions. Pricey, but worth it. Have been once, but will definitely go again.

0Qa-RRi8PB2ecz_tfdRQIg.text: Decided to try this place out since I have tried Lemongrass next door and loved it. Our server Victor was very friendly and provided excellent service. I loved the design inside and everything they used inside from the napkins (its pink!), to the  utensils, plates, etc. Loved the pink blossom theme. I really liked the spicy sauces brought out on the side. Loved the soy sauce with all the peppers in it. Ordered jasmine tea and it was so good. I drank a lot of tea. For dishes I got the walnut shrimp and the spicy chicken hot pot. Both was very delicious. Loved everything about the dishes. It was well put together in taste and presentation. I liked the fruits (melons) that came with the walnut shrimp. The shrimps were big and flavorful. The spicy chicken hot pot sauce was so good! I liked the green vegetable they put in it, it gave a lot of flavor! I loved the mushrooms with the spicy chicken. Chicken was moist and good. There are some small bones so just be careful eating it. We were so full afterwards we had no room for dessert. Definitely enjoyed my experience here.

Amazing. The garlic fried lobster was everything!! The noodles are exactly how you wish noodles tasted every time.  I can't say enough about this meal - service was outstanding too.

xpLcJeCyS1uRc7gwhTLxNQ.text: This place is in the Aria. So right away its elegant and expensive. The first time i went they gave me some BS about not being able to get food to go. This turned out to be wrong and i suspect they were just giving me attitude..sorry sir its gourmet food,WTF? I have eaten at many restaurants that were gourmet ,was never denied getting it to go. The second time i went there the food was good but the service was horrid.As a result of complaining the second time i was told i could now get food to go which i did the third time. Over all I would say its about a 6.5 out of 10. I have had superior Chinese food at much less prices and at higher or comparable prices. Bottom line if you are aria its a Chinese food choice. They need to work on their service for the prices they charge its poor.

ZzwOfnGQqKf5GONCZdQk8g.text: The restaurant has a nice ambiance and the food was well made.  We made reservations ahead of time so there was hardly any wait on a Saturday.  The orders came in a timely manner and decently portioned.   The service was great until the end when we were trying to get the attention of any server to get our check.  They seemed to forget about our table once the restaurant got progressively busy.

KH8YuxoSBmFUlNbPraohmw.text: The concierge at the Aria recommended this place to me and my buddy. I was almost certain he was just pushing one of their restaurants, but I'm glad I did not give into my paranoia as this was the best Chinese meal I have had in my life. As someone who has eaten a lot of Chinese food (across the entire spectrum of qualities), I can confidently say this.  Atmosphere: phenomenal  Service: also phenomenal - our waitress was extremely helpful in helping us order, it was as if she was as determined to pick exactly the right items as us. She recommended exactly the right amount of food and despite the numerous land mines on the menu (which I define as exceptionally expensive items inconspicuously hidden amongst normal priced items), she focused solely on what was relatively normally priced.  Cocktails: These were very good. Not mind blowing but in the top 20% of restaurant cocktails I've had.  Food: Most important item hit it out of the park. Despite eating a lot of it, I did not feel sick whatsoever afterwords. Most items were very common orders at a Chinese restaurant but very clean and high quality. I split with my friend the pork appetizer, pork dumplings, kung pao chicken, and some side I can't remember. I would describe the food as similar to Mr. Chow but better.

t8iOHj3JNQJ5o6RXmtV5jA.text: One of the BEST Chinese restaurants Las Vegas has to offer!    As any Foodie knows, Las Vegas is home to some of the GREATEST restaurants in the country, Blossom is NO exception!  I have dined here twice and both times received EXCELLENT service and OUTSTANDING dishes!    My second time here I treated a few casino hosts to dinner that have never been here and even they were impressed!  The decor is ultra modern, very comfortable, and spacious.  From the moment you sit down, the great service begins from Blossom's friendly and courteous staff.  You will NEVER need to flag anyone down, they are aware of your every move and will anticipate your every need before you have to ask, thus allowing you to enjoy your meal, drinks, and company to perfection!    THE FOOD: There are many great dishes here, and truth be told I don't believe you will ever have a bad meal here.  For starters I would recommend the Egg Rolls with Bell Pepper, Pot Stickers (Pork), BBQ Back Ribs, and their Hot and Sour Soup!  Any and all of these will be sure to please any taste palate and prepare you for amazing main courses to come.  For main courses, you can again, order many dishes that are large enough to share family style.  The Peeking Duck may be a bit pricey, but it is very good and served in wraps (A bit different than the norm, but VERY good)  I also recommend the Mongolian Beef, Kung Pao Chicken, and Beef Tenderloin in Black Pepper Sauce.  All are excellent dishes!    THE BOTTOM LINE: Blossom is at the TOP of my list for Chinese dining while in Las Vegas, this place is consistently EXCELLENT in both food and customer service!  The ambiance is both inviting and comfortable, and allows you to hold conversations among your party at a reasonable level without having to shout.  Enjoy!

3pKsVqCUE65iaai-Z7GUbA.text: Way better than the food in Spring mountain rd. highly recommended for the one who miss Cantonese cuisine.

photos.caption: Photo of Blossom - Las Vegas, NV, United States

tDGniQ6mnyqyRI2PUOK5Cw.text: My favorite Chinese food in Vegas. The tempura string beans are heaven. The service is almost too good, with so many staff that if you look away from the table someone is instantly asking what you need.

photos.caption: Photo of Blossom - Las Vegas, NV, United States

-IGqEzr0SEvmamQlc_4qmw.text: This was our first restaurant when we arrived in Aria. We were so hungry we didn't put our bags up to our room.   Chilies (see pic) = $6.50 Beef Chow Fun = $22 Indian Fried Rice = $18 Large Prawn in Mayo with cashew = $24 Jasmine tea = $5.50/ person  Total $120 for three people  If you go online you'll find their menu but no price. Why? Because they're cool like that. No, it's because they want you to come in based on the restaurant decor and let the premium price of beef chow fun slided. It worked on us, or maybe we were butt hungry and don't want to be walking around looking for food.  All three dishes were really good. The flavoring were spot on. It wasn't too salty or too bland. Surprisingly this has been an issue with some of the restaurants I've visited. "Sage" which is considered one of the top restaurants in Aria, their food were way too salty. See Sage review when I get to it.  Skip to recap, this is a funny incident. So we waited for a friend who lives in LV. When he got to our table the first thing he said, aloud was, "I'm so fucking plaster drunk!" He sat down take a drink of the tea, "Fuck this is good. Hey waiter get me a bottle!" Mind you we never met this guy. Then he waved the waiter over and asked if he can smoked a cigarette, "No sir, there's no smoking in here." "Ok, no problem." The waiter walked a way and guess what he did. Yeap, he lit a cigarette. A second later a manager ran over asked him to put it out he said, "Ok, ok" and pursue to sucking on the cigarette repeatedly until there weren't anymore then he putted it out. Hilarious.   I left out something. He offered me a cigarette. I don't smoke don't like smoke but I was done with the food and I like humor and I'm curious. So let's see what would happened. So he and I lit a cigarette. That was fun. I'm sure nobody enjoyed that experience except us. What? I didn't say I'm an angel.  Recaps: Food flavor spot on Beautiful restaurant decor Excellent service Jasmine tea here is the bomb. They probably grab this from heaven. Best jasmine tea I've tasted now that I think about it.  Pricing is not heaven send, it's -- wait for it... legendary!!! I'm trying to say that it was very expensive. Beef chow fun for $22?! Where I come from Sam Woo bust that out for $3.99 yo! and the tea was free. But then again your in LV can't do apple to apple comparison. The food were clean and elegant. You can tell the chef/cook got skills. It's not sloppy it's well put together, well timed, well flavors. Well I noticed these things anyway - yeap I was trained and look where it got me, middle of no where. Sorry off topic.   I would go back delicious Chinese food. We left a big tip for being an ass. I'm sure we're forgiven. Heck, they even welcome us back tomorrow.

photos.caption: Photo of Blossom - Las Vegas, NV, United States. After a bad flight chiles is a good wake me up!

IqRqgG8IuyF_GT9HKMhq7w.text: This is the type of smart restaurant establishments thats opened up in Vegas for all the high roller Asians thatve come from Asia or locally that are sick of going to Chinatown to get their Chinese food fix. Its also a beautiful, sophisticated ambiance, great for impressing a group of Business clients or date night. The food was pretty good, but the ambiance made up for it.  The best was the Garlic Prawn fried rice. Im always impressed when fancy restaurants could make a simple dish taste so unique and enjoyable without packing on the salt.  I had also asked for a side of XO spicy sauce that i noticed they had on the lobster fried rice. This sauce is AMAZING as a spicy kick to your dishes, or for me, just devoured that plate as a side dish. Theyve made this in-house with dried shrimp and scallop. I will warn you though (since the waitor didnt), that they will charge you 6$ for this. But i found it well worth it if youre a Spicy/Seafood lover like me.  The next best thing thats a must is their "Steamed Seabass & Tofu". That fish tasted like pure butter, melted right in my mouth, atop the soft tofu, finished with thin slices of scallion, spices & black bean sauce.  The other dishes we ordered that were pretty good, but not "MUSTS" were the Beef tenderloin with portabella mushrooms (quality beef, but too salty), pan-fried beef with sweet ginger & pineapple and kungpao chicken.  Id highly recommend this place!

4EmugmADZ7rFQZzww-qslA.text: What were we thinking?  The combination of food we ordered just didn't work.  Peking Duck-Choice of buns or pancakes.  Go with the pancakes.  We asked to try both.  The buns are good, but the thin pancakes definitely allow the flavors to come through.  My wife liked the cucumber and scallions, but I could have done without the cucumber.  It detracted from the dish.  The duck was good and presentation and service was excellent, but I have had a crispier skinned duck at a better price here in Hawai'i.  Crispy Chilean Sea Bass-Thick, crunchy crust. This dish lacked presentation and its textures were not complementary.  Two steaks leaning on a mound of shredded daikon. The crust was hard to break through. I marveled at its crunchiness, and the wife thought it was gummy.  Flavors were good, soy sauce, peanut oil?, and scallions. However, the delicate, fresh fish was not allowed to shine because of that thick crust which was also quite oily.  Yang Chow Fried Rice-Char siu (pork) and shrimp.  Typical, but the shrimp was abundant and cooked perfectly...and a little oily.    Pea shoots-Sauteed with garlic.  There was a lot of garlic...a whole lot, but it was good....  Food service was very good.  Water service was poor.   On our part, food selection could have been better.  We left the restaurant feeling like we had just eaten at a greasy spoon.  The duck we expected to be fatty, but everything we ordered seemed to be oily.  Considering the price point, I expected better.  This is a decent restaurant that uses quality ingredients.  Some dishes are a little off the mark and in the wrong combination, can make the meal a fail.

WOMwxKAYbqXb44-BQt6R9w.text: Great service and incredible food!  We wound up here for a business dinner without a reservation and were really surprised that this place wasn't packed.    Our entire party was pleased with the quality of food we got.  We started with the tempura ice fish and the beef roll with enoki mushroom.  Both were spectacular (although how can a pile of little fried fish be anything but?).  Everyone ordered their own entree and didn't really share, but for me, the steamed sea bass on tofu was a great follow up to the heavier appetizers.  The sauce sufficiently allowed the sea bass to shine through.  The fish itself was perfectly flaky.  The tofu added more substance to the dish while not making it heavy.  Can't think of any way to improve this one!    The service was also impeccable.  We were never waiting for drinks and the waiter was always right there if we had a question or wanted to order something.  Even though he was very attentive, he didn't hover.    All in all, a great experience and a pleasant surprise.  If you are looking for some authentic Chinese food and don't want to venture off the strip, add Blossom to your list of options.  You won't be disappointed.

sho9xTbnrplZssuwx1GkdA.text: We came here last year during a company event, so money wasn't an issue. I crafted a theme for every night and Blossom was my one Chinese night. As a Chinese American who grew up with excellent Cantonese food, I have to say this wasn't the best Cantonese food I've ever had. However, it was the most expensive Cantonese food I've ever had.

41KyGtD4iPiHq6Y_RcmylA.text: We ordered Jian Bo beef, Ma Po tofu. The beef was so salty we had to send it back. Second time it was almost the same. Still too salty to eat. We had to send back and have the waiter take it off the bill. One of the waiters didn't seem so glad. Will not go back.

XDke92tXvSL-WPexImKUMA.text: Very very good traditional Chinese food with amazing service! I think it's slightly overpriced for what you get and that's why I did 4 stars. Overall...good food and good service!

hlilynPprxwo4-BCLMINXg.text: All the Yelp reviews led me here to Blossom. My partner and I were celebrating our 3.5 year anniversary, so we wanted to splurge and find a place with good eats. Everyone had something positive to say here and so we decided to check it out. We made a last minute reservation and thus, seating and dining was quite effortless from there.   This restaurant business is tucked away from the hustle and bustle of drunks and gamblers (aka away from the slot machines and card tables). You'll know you're going the right way when you see the golden statue/fountain right out front.  We were a little hesitant to get Chinese food in Vegas, but we thoroughly enjoyed our stay and the meals at the ARIA so we decided this place had to be just as good. And we were RIGHT.  Our meal consisted of: - the Walnut Prawns - the Beef Chow Fun - Stuffed Crabcakes/Meatballs (I think) - a vegetable dish  It's been awhile since I was there so it's kind of hard for me to remember all of the details. But the Walnut Praws were my favorite part of the dinner. They were so large and succulent, my tastebuds were watering. The Crabcakes/Meatballs were very thick, but the sweet and sour sauce they added made it a lot easier to eat, and enjoyable too.  The hostess and our waiter were all excellent. They provided us with water all the time, asked us if we were okay or if we needed anything else, and so kindly wrapped our leftovers so we could take it back to the hotel room.  I'd definitely recommend this place if you want upscale Chinese food. The pricing of each dish here is rather on the more expensive side of Chinese cuisine. Expect to pay between $20-30 for each entree you decide to get. Sharing it family style makes it a lot more manageable and tastier too!  I hope you enjoy this place as much as I did!

HvzuiJtSesgpOns90ZaGlQ.text: Probably the best Chinese food I had in a long time. The decor is very classy!! Servers are friendly and they really do give good recommendation for the food. I personally  recommend the enoki mushroom wrap with beef and Seabass!!! Oh I almost forget, they have the best garlic prawn fried rice I ever had!! The price is decent!!

photos.caption: Photo of Blossom - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Blossom - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy Seabass
Photo of Blossom - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic Prawn Fried Rice

nEvcz00DRMh4XPBWAFd28A.text: Truly a remarkable dining experience! While we had pedestrian vegetarian cuisine, the service was truly remarkable. We came in in hoop shorts with sweat on our brow and Kenny treated us like royalty. Now I don't know who in the hell is going to order a $36,000 bottle of wine but the veggie chow mein and the fried tofu appetizer are second to none. Do yourself a solid and hit up blossom next time you're in Sin City

e78MvKMWRMBAXeCMFw5nEQ.text: This is the best Chinese restaurant I've ate in Las Vegas!!! All the seafood are fresh and lots of dishes with different flavor you can try!!! Also I like the servers here, they're really nice and patient!!! Come to eat if you are in Las Vegas

6GJdrFuViiBt8yMrL7QbXA.text: One item on the menu simply says: WALNUT SHRIMP with mayonnaise.  What is served is an exquisite combination of lightly breaded giant shrimp laced with mayonnaise sauce over a bed of cut cantaloupe and honeydew melon, randomly complemented with candied walnut pieces touched by sesame seeds. The combination is simply mouthwatering.  Amazing.

gjznAfzW5l5LenXXs7OF9w.text: Best Chinese food I've ever had! Everything was awesome and our waiter was super cool. Only negative was the banana split dessert, skip it.

HYHczJ1y8Jv0kkxB5DqELg.text: Shrimp Chow Mein was excellent. The shrimp were large. The ribs did not have enough flavor. Restaurant is beautiful, but service was not up to par this time. It was not busy.

SYIegGof9rWmm4NvX6WvwQ.text: Everything I ordered from here was amazing The service  The atmosphere The menu I had the wonton soup, sea bass, duck, wine, thier dumplings are thier signature dish- amazing  Would definitely recommend

-pcmx3Hcwn93Ro3s8DAWDg.text: We wanted something small and light before going to see Zarkana at Aria, and we were not disappointed. We eat got a soup to start, I had the wonton, my husband had the soup of the day (I can't renege what is called, I just remember it had sweet potatoes in it) and the had lots of flavor workout being heavy.  The rest of our meal was a series of small plates off of the appetizer menu, but the shitaki mushrooms stood out as something unique and delicious. If we go back to Vegas, I would be happy to go back to have a full dinner.

f9i5bAaDPCqYffuepRHfiA.text: One of my favorite places to dine in Vegas.  Atmosphere is very classy, great service and not as noisy as other nearby restaurants.  I had mapo tofu, well seasoned and slightly acidic the way I like it.  Will try the Peking duck next time.

-d92ySLHTdfLVv3X-fTorw.text: This is really 3.5 stars. The environment is awesome. Beautiful set up, pleasant light, seats and decor. Service was variable...there was one guy who was just excellent and made our night! Wish I got his name. Such an awesome employee. He wasn't our waiter but came by several times. Looked like he was possibly a manager. Our waiters were fine. Forgot a couple of things but then brought them, nothing too exceptional. Food was good, but severely overpriced. This is Chinese for goodness sake. $76 duck is unreasonable. We got two other different main courses and they were good, just not $150 bill good. I just don't see what warrants these prices.   We were there for my husband's birthday and they were really nice acknowledging that. We had a complimentary desert and a small birthday box with tea, which was a very sweet touch.   Next time I eat Chinese will be probably in 3-4 years.

PJZC-N8dfEmxVj0u-UbvbA.text: Good food just show all the food next time when you come around in carts.  We would love to be showed the sticky rice.

6zMTa9P8BJRgGlsGNohUJA.text: Blossom is an absolutely beautiful restaurant inside the Aria Hotel.  The decor was modern with kind of a neo-Asian decor.  This is the type of 5-star experience, where the waitstaff is 100%  there to serve you.  We were welcomed at the door, promptly seated and treated like royalty.  Here you can get your typical Chinese entree for $290 or a bottle of wine for $44,000.  However, we chose several entrees ranging from $20-$30 and our sommelier, Simon, chose a lovely bottle of zinfandel for around $50. I really enjoyed the Kung Pao shrimp, as the prawns were huge and flavorful. Just watch for those dried red peppers.   I also enjoyed the Spicy on Spicy pork dish.  This is more of a formal dining experience than a party place.  I would love to reserve one of the large private dining alcoves with a chandelier next time.

gD2CRtVaZKHrUVNQDwpvgA.text: Very good Chinese food!  especially the Beijing Duck , So delicious. Even Better than DaDong, the famous Beijing Duck restaurant in Beijing! The service is great too.  a little bit pricy, but definitely worth!

vH7JcGsWKwRFT6BjTVRLrg.text: Very expensive - even for Las Vegas. My wife had the pot stickers and the Wor Wonton soup which was a very small bowl for $14 and was quite  tasteless and had 2 wontons, 1 shrimp and 1 scallop - we asked for hot sauce. The 5 pot stickers were ok. I had Mapo Tofu which was rather dull / only a fairly liquid sauce but no other content but the tofu - nothing exciting - and I have had many Mapo Tofus. Our 2 gin Martinis came to $34 and were quite small/meager. Wont't be back.

qOBoPkrWpw-2QFmNw-f1jA.text: This will be my very first review for Yelp.  I don't normally write reviews because 99% of the times I eat out I am with my husband Dennis T.  Now, for those of you who are familiar with Dennis' reviews you will understand why I don't find it necessary to write reviews.  He says it all, and in a much more creative and descriptive way than I ever could.  Who would want to follow his act?  Dennis decided for Valentine's Day that we would eat at Blossom in Aria and follow it up with the Viva ELVIS show.  Excellent choices, but I won't be reviewing either one.  My sole reason for writing this review is to make you and the management at Blossom aware of an excellent server named Jackson V.  Immediately after I was seated he presented me with a perfect long stemmed red rose for Valentine's Day.  That was a very nice surprise, but not the reason for my review.  Jackson was simply one of the nicest servers I have ever encountered.   We asked what kind of hot tea they had and after naming three types we weren't sure if we wanted Oolong or Jasmine.  We expressed to Jackson that we thought it was Oolong that we liked and ordered a pot.  After he poured our tea and we both tasted it he inquired how we liked it.  I said it was okay, but I really think I prefer Jasmine.  Without our prompting he immediately went to the kitchen and procured a piping hot order of Jasmine tea and gave each of us new teacups.  Now Dennis has two teacups in front of him and when he went to pour the second cup of Oolong tea for himself he learned just how hot that pot was and spilled the tea in the process.  Jackson and another server immediately appeared to clean up the mess.  Dennis ordered potstickers as an appetizer and asked for and received five different sauces to complement them, including a small vial of red wine vinegar.  Dennis did not know to hold on to the top when pouring the vinegar.  You guessed it, the top came off and red wine vinegar was splattered all down the front of his shirt in a curious polka dot pattern.  This time three servers rushed to our rescue.  Jackson left and promptly returned with a glass of club soda and small cloth so we could attempt to clean up his shirt, to no avail.  Now I am probably one of the pickiest eaters in the country.  I hate all vegetables (except potatoes if you consider that a vegetable), only eat a couple of fruits, and don't like anything spicy.  Even black pepper is too much for my sensitive palate.  You know how they say your taste buds change every seven years?  Well mine are still stuck at age seven!  I ordered the Wor Wonton Soup without any vegetables because Jackson said it wouldn't be a problem and I did receive it sans vegetables.  I ordered the Honey Walnut Shrimp without the fruit and it also was presented the way I ordered it.  Everything we asked for we promptly received from a smiling Jackson who was not even slightly fazed by my weird ordering style or Dennis' mishaps.  Blossom's management should know what a gem they have in Jackson.  He was efficient, courteous and friendly and Dennis and I will request him the next time we dine there, and I highly recommend you do the same.   By the way, the food was also excellent and deserves this five-star rating.

m3uR45c2bApF4KrI7jEfow.text: Absolutely spectacular service and delicious food.  Blossom knocked it out of the park.  I can count on one hand the places that I've been with this level of service. Our server was incredibly helpful and welcoming. He was clearly invested in us enjoying every aspect of our experience in the restaurant, and there were ample support staff to make it a flawless experience. It was pretty formal, but I still felt like I was being cared for as if I were in someones home. We got some great vegetable dishes to share and my boyfriend got a noodle dish as well. Everything we got was delicious. The portions weren't gigantic for the price, but everything was so good that we'd definitely go back. The atmosphere is pretty spectacular, too.   Going to Blossom was one of our favorite aspects of our trip to Vegas.

s_wci5PMHa0emf7hIx9oKg.text: I'd give a 4 or 5 star, but we called for a reservation for 13.  When we got there, they had put two round tables together for us.  Two round table didn't fit 13 people.  We asked if they had rectangle or square table they said no.  They did have a private room to fit 13 people and the minimum was over $2,000.  They waived the minimum, which was nice, but even in the private room, we sat at two round tables, separate.  We ordered separately, the food didn't come out at the same time, the drinks didn't come out of the same time, etc.  The food was good.  I guess it's not good for big groups.

sffthO07pArcrGksQYOdFg.text: Typical inconvenient casino & resort parking, nothing new around here.  Ordered Pho, Yellow Curry, and Ribeye steak with Tamarind sauce. The steak was delivered barely luke warm, Yellow Curry was w-a-y too sweet and not enough curry spices, and didn't know any restaurant could prepare Pho wrong.   The server was super nice, rewarmed my steak, and offered to replace if I didn't like anything about it. He's the reason for two stars. Otherwise, it would have been just one.

IpgHQj0JGAcddxC6au4-NQ.text: Items Selected:  Sacred Fruit - Vodka, Lychee, Orchid Goose Liver - Touch of Black Pepper, Daikon, Carrots Golden Seafood Medallion - Cream Cheese, Shrimp, Crab Meat on Toast Walnut Prawns - Topped with Mayonnaise, Candied Walnuts, over Winter Melons Peking Duck - Carved Tableside, Hoisin, Bao, Wraps Sesame Cookies Dim Sum Dumplings - Cinnamon, Sesame, Coconut with Kahlua Cream, Chocolate and Passion Fruit Dips Pineapple Cake and Tea Takeaway  Having spent the vast majority of my life in Ohio and thus isolated from most Asian cultures save for during my travels I'm embarrassed to say that prior to relocating to Las Vegas I'd never truly realized the grandeur of the Chinese New Year, a fete celebrated by nearly 20% of the world's 6.5 billion people, but vowing to remedy this situation through both a literature search and at least a couple meals commemorating the Year of the Horse it was with good fortune that I found a friend happy to join me at Aria's highly praised Blossom on Saturday night.  Seemingly a cuisine underappreciated by many Americans, or at least most frequently enjoyed 'on the cheap,' yet one whose bold flavors I'd previously seen brought to new light by exemplary ingredients in both Toronto and New York it was just after 7:30pm when my friend and I arrived for dinner and seated at a plush two-top given full vantage of the room's center dining area it was with stellar service from a team of at least a half dozen that the night progressed; a cocktail, quartet of savories, and a single dessert plus complimentary cookies served in three courses with every plate stunning in quality, quantity, and presentation.  Starting off with a duo of creamy True/goose foie gras with pronounced sapor balanced by light pepper and seared caramelization served alongside four "medallions" melding concepts of Crab Rangoon and Shrimp Toast it would be difficult to name another spot in the States to find a better version of either, yet progressing to the 'main course' it was soon that round one disappeared to the ages as Chef Chi Kwun Choi's farm raised Peking Duck arrived tableside to be deftly carved and plated by a veteran service team claiming to have performed the ritual "at least two thousand times," the crisp and meaty skin placed delicately on bao and in pancakes with crisp vegetable and aromatic hoisin before the rest of the bird was taken to the kitchen to be disarticulated, deboned, and presented hot, supple, and ever so rich.  Rounded out with large, lightly fried prawns and candied walnuts topped with delicately honeyed mayo over chilled winter melons and finally six small dumplings filled with silky Kahlua cream plus a duo of gifts for the table it would be easy for me to say Blossom was the best Chinese restaurant I've experienced to date but taking it one step further I'd place it amongst my ten best meals in Las Vegas; food, room, and service rivaling some of the French, Spanish, and Italian Masters at a slightly more favorable price point.

DeKDICoRHxaEYwrTWOR51A.text: I have been to plenty and I mean plenty of Chinese and Hong Kong cuisine restaurants. Blossom has stood out, they do their own mix on traditional dishes. I recommend the Beef Chow Fun, Walnut Prawns, & the Fried Flounder. The walnut prawns are by far the best I've ever had, they are not completely soaked in the mayonnaise. There is enough drizzle to where you can still taste the shrimp. And placed underneath is a mound of cantaloupe and honeydew, I have never tasted a more perfect combination. The flounder is fried to a crisp and juicy. Overall, you're paying for what you get and this is a must stop in Vegas.

sqKsG6CFBBCGKcor1XSKHg.text: Don't come here looking for cheap , MSG laden, buffet style Chinese, they only serve awesome al a carte  style dishes.  This place has some of the best Chinese food. Ample portions , good quality cuts of meat (chicken and beef is what we had)  and lots of vegetables.   We each ordered a dish with a side of fried rice. I would recommend ordering just one dish per couple along with a fried rice dish. Everything was fresh.   Service was absolutely outstanding. Not overly intrusive but right there when you needed some water or other amenity. Very personable and answered every question.   I will make it a point to come back here again in every trip to Vegas.

hRH9YWW_H5WPdapZSNIDzw.text: Hands down the best Chinese food in Las Vegas. I've visited other places before and they do not even compare. We started our meal off with the BBQ Pork appetizer and it was amazing. Great start to the meal.  I had the Mongolian Beef and my wife had the Kung Pow Chicken. We both shared a nice big portion of fried rice with pork and shrimp. Both dishes were the best we had in Vegas on our whole trip.  Whenever we return to Vegas this will definitely be on our list to visit again.

r_vyKcV_QIr_yeNVu4aHnw.text: Best restaurant in Vegas in my opinion. The $100 Peking Duck is expensive, but superb, and the decor is just excellent. The pea shoots are also amazing here, perfect crunch and good amount of salt. So I didn't strike it big in Vegas, but I did go home with a delicious meal. Located inside Aria!

qtJ-cJk7BzoTuUWcBsMIQw.text: The thing about the high-end restaurants in Las Vegas is that so many of them are offshoots of famous restaurants in New York City, San Francisco, Los Angeles, or Miami Beach. I skip most of them on my trips to Vegas because I can go to the exact same restaurant in New York City (or San Francisco or Miami Beach or LA).   Blossom is a restaurant that you will find only in Las Vegas. Prior to my first time at Blossom about half a decade ago, I would never have thought that I would travel to Vegas to dine at a Chinese restaurant. The Hong Kong style black pepper goose liver appetizer at Blossom has forever changed my views about the use of offal in Chinese cuisine. It's unlike anything else I've found anywhere else in the US. The best way I can describe it is foie gras with a delightful black pepper kick. I will sometimes get 3 servings of this phenomenal appetizer as my main dish.   Another unique appetizer that Blossom used to offer was the seafood medallions. This was like the lovechild of shrimp toast and crab rangoon. Much to my dismay, this menu item was discontinued a few years ago.   Service is very courteous and attentive, and prices are reasonable, given the excellent quality of the food and service.

O8sOZwvsaOAmKSRqChFGKQ.text: Located inside the Aria Hotel this ranks highly among the best in Chinese fine dining.  If you're up for a big splurge and want to experience some delicacy seafood items in a nice upscale setting, accompanied with exemplary service (a rarity in most Chinese restaurants), give Blossom a try.  You'll find some Crazy Rich Asian-types here (of which I am not one), going all out in dining at this beautiful, Strip restaurant.  It can be compared to Wing Lei at the Wynn or Jasmine at the Bellagio, but in a more modern and intimate setting.  The evening started in an interesting way, as my waiter acknowledged me by my full name, welcomed me back, and proceeded to recite the precise date I was last there, down to the month, date and year.  I'm sure the stats are all in their system, but I've never ever experienced this.  A little odd, in a Big Brother sort of a way, but sounds like he was just abiding to their protocol.  I came specifically this time to try one specific dish, the "Natural Nine".  It consists of all my favorites, being fish maw, sea cucumber, abalone, lobster, chicken wings, mushrooms, duck feet, and bundled yam noodles.  It can be ordered as a hot pot, or braised.  I was initially planning on ordering the hot pot version, but opted instead for the braised preparation after a lengthy discussion with my waiter.   As it turns out, he made a great suggestion, and the dish, which served four for $168.00 was excellent!!  I particularly loved the fish maw and sea cucumbers.  I had requested that it be made with less salt, as some Chinese braised items can be overly salted, and my request was well accommodated.  I was there dining solo, but I ate enough for at least two, and took the remaining home.  I had some left over rice and asked to take it back.  They very nicely offered to provide me with fresh rice, for no additional cost.  When I got home, I was very pleased to find a nice sized container of fresh rice.  A very nice touch, which I've experienced in Chinese restaurants in Las Vegas, but never ever at any Bay Area Chinese restaurant, fancy or not.    I'd say to pass on the wonton soup appetizer.  The accompaniments of the scallop and shrimp were good, but I really didn't like the odd tasting pork inside the wonton.  Frankly, I've had better tasting wontons in dives than I had here.  I should've known better than to order an every day dish in a fancy schmancy restaurant like this.    At the end of dinner, the waiter said that because I liked abalone, I might be interested in their abalone dishes, and shared a menu that focused just on abalone dishes, and another that was bird nest centric.  It would've been nice to see these menus at the beginning of dinner, though. Maybe a "secret menu"? If abalone dishes or bird nest dishes sound appealing to you, then ask for these separate menus up front.  Did I mention service here is also among the best I've ever experienced in Chinese restaurants including those in Asia?  My waiter, Danny, and the ancillary staff were all attentive, pouring my tea almost every time they walked by.  During my discussion about the specialty Chinese dessert soup of the day,  Danny, who only spoke Mandarin and knowing I only understood Cantonese, voluntarily brought over a Cantonese speaking waiter, who explained the dessert in detail to me in Cantonese.  That was nice, and definitely an anomaly for me.  What a welcomed departure from the curt service I'm accustomed to in the majority of Chinese restaurants!!  Of note is a change in policy I wasn't aware of.  When the restaurant phoned to confirm my reservation, they informed me that there is now a business casual dress code, and children under six are no longer permitted.  It didn't bother me, as I wasn't planning on dressing sloppily, nor was I planning on bringing any young children.  However, if you are planning on doing either, you may want to rethink a visit here.  Definitely a nice venue for high end Chinese.  Given the price, if you're planning on ordering more common Chinese dishes that you can easily find anywhere else, like chow mein, kung pao chicken or wonton soup, I'd say pass.  However, definitely make this a stop for more "exotic" seafood and specialty items here, which will not disappoint!

uh07a3sR_7Vejs_mySYU6Q.text: I've been here a few times now and I really like it. Most recently, I came for dinner on a Saturday night. The restaurant ended up getting pretty full, but it was easy to get a reservation.   From the start, the service and the ambiance were great. Blossom is really quiet compared to many other places on the strip. Kinda like being in a spa. Service was friendly and very attentive.  Food comes across as very traditional and classic. Everything I had was worth the price. There are a lot of very expensive items on the menu, but I didn't try any of those this time.   In terms of food I did have: - Hot & sour soup was good but spicier than I expected - Wor wonton soup was good if kinda standard  - Hong Kong style chow mein with scallops, fish, and shrimp was great. Noodles were crispy and seafood was perfectly-cooked.  - Kung pao chicken was a nice elevation of the dish with lots of flavor  I also had a "matcha spice" cocktail which was fine, but I wouldn't get it again. They do have a very extensive wine list if you're into that.  EDIT: Also, they gave us a nice box with some jasmine tea and a pineapple pastry to go with out check!

TcD2Sy_yQwR7zYr-LGI1-g.text: We came here for dinner a few nights ago and my fiance loooved it!! I wish I could give this place a 4.5 stars because 4 stars doesn't do it justice and it's not quite up to 5 stars yet. The service was IMPECCABLE. And I don't say that with levity. We ordered the shiitake appetizer, the hot and sour soup, fried eggplant appetizer, the Hong Kong style lobster, the filet stir fry, and the string beans. The shiitake appetizer was the worst part because they made it super sweet and the texture was gummy. We didn't eat much of it. The eggplant and hot and sour soup were good in my opinion but my fiance loooved it way more than I did- I just thought they could have used more flavor. I really enjoyed the filet stir fry; it was extremely authentic and reminded me of eating dinner when I was a kid. The lobster was done well...but I was expecting a different kind of Hong Kong style that I'm used to eating in Chinatown in Boston when I was a kid.  The string beans were good too. They also had a great selection of Chinese alcoholic beverages :) overall great job and I'll definitely come back.

Qg3l9hMAoZR-2cAYCPAQeQ.text: Came here with a family friend who's a high roller and he ordered pretty much a 10 star course meal.    Spicy Sour Soup (just a starter, nothing fancy) Peking Duck Lobster Sashimi Alaskan King Crab Rock Cod fish Some fancy smancy aged red wine Kobe Beef Fried large prawns  Now mind you, all this was comped!  =)  Nothing beats free.  But i'm sure they gambled a lot of $$$.  Hey, hope they won, but whatever. Back to the review.  Now, I'm not sure about their normal food, but these dishes were top notch.  The raw ingredients used matters, but it was also flavorful and well cooked.  The kobe beef had to be the best if you are a meat person.  The fat juice just burst out of the meat with every bite.    The alaskan king crab was also great, so rich and full.     The large prawns and soup was probably the most mediocre in this lineup.  I wouldn't want to eat this stuff everyday though.  The Cholestrol would kill you.

XFgZdY_ZJ0vb4CO-ZpkSzQ.text: What a delicious dinner at Blossom Chinese Restaurant located inside Aria Resort. From mouthwatering goose liver appetizer to the sweet ending Creme Brulee dessert, our bellies were treated to a scrumptious dinner. The prawns were huge, fresh, and flavorful. The lobster dish with ginger and scallions was delectable. Their interesting take on the Creme Brulee really put this whole experience over the top. The restaurant was gorgeous, and the staff were experience and friendly. Happy bellies for both hubby and I last night.

33vpKpUg5hald6K_oXCVOg.text: When you want a great authentic Asian meal and are in the Vegas area, blossom is the place to go. Located in the aria hotel, it has a beautiful interior decor and something about the place made it seem extremely elegant and intimate. We ordered several dishes including the Peking duck. It may have been the best Peking duck I've ever had. Sliced to perfection accompanied by the bao buns. Their fried rice was cooked perfectly with the perfect amount of rice. We ordered about 2 drinks each and some apps and the prices are extremely reasonable. Great portions for a dinner either before going out into the Las Vegas party scene or just to have dinner with some friends and enjoy a relaxing gambling filled night. When I'm back in Vegas I will definitely be back at blossom.

Gut6JgtRKUtDnMw1qGLhQA.text: Where do I start? Definitely the best Chinese restaurant in Vegas. Expensive for Chinese food, but very much worth it. The Peking Duck is cut table side and placed on a plate for you to make your own wraps. The fresh live prawns are steamed to perfection and very sweet in flavor. The Chinese sausage fried rice pairs well with all the dishes and is a must order. I wish we had a bigger group to try more dishes, but from what we had I know that everything else is probably pretty bomb. The service also deserves some compliments because the servers were more than pleasant! Let's just say, I will be back!

lmrc5IyVEKkJ-PGMIma2sA.text: Elegant, refined, and beautifully executed Chinese food. Blossom is my go to for upscale Chinese food in Vegas. The chicken corn chowder was nuanced and comforting. The Chinese Sausage Fried rice is the best I've ever had and the beef and seafood dishes are always well executed. The Peking duck is wonderfully prepared and carved trackside. V4DzCerF_dO4_gbLR08qtg.text: This was a beautiful restaurant with excellent service. It's located inside the Aria. Everyone was so welcoming and kind. Our water was always full (which is something I really appreciate).   As for the food, I was quite disappointed. For an appetizer, we ordered the salt and paper squid. It had a nice crunch to it, almost like calamari. I was looking for a little more salt in this dish since it was lacking in flavor. For dinner, we ordered the BBQ duck (not the Peking Duck), chow fun, fried Chilean Sea Bass, and Broccoli beef. Out of all the dishes, the Chilean sea bass was the best. It had the right amount of salt and a great sauce paired with it. As for the other dishes, I found myself putting the chili sauce on everything because the dishes weren't as flavorful. The BQQ duck was not BBQed enough. The beef broccoli (unfortunately) was under season as well as the chow fun. So for the pricing of everything, I was not satisfied. Though it was a pleasant experience, I do not think I was WOWed enough to revisit this restaurant. But thank you for a great time, Blossom!

KGbHD_CfM-qae5uoFxTblQ.text: The service here was really good. The staff was very nice. I love the decor. The food was tasty. We had a preset dinner, Including chicken with snow peas, broccoli beef, bbq pork chow mein, and shrimp with bamboo shoots. The chow mein was tasty although my least favorite because I was anticipating crispy noodles. I ordered the Cherry Blossom drink and it was OK but a tad too sweet. I would visit again.

Qh8CAD4haRnlaax8SEgswg.text: With this Blossom visit we've now eaten our way around all the Aria restaurants (and a lot of other world-class eateries in USA and Canada). We unintentionally saved one of the best for last!  Let me get this out of the way- Blossom is pricey, it is very expensive on a per-dish basis.  With that said, when going to Vegas and expecting a very good experience, you should always simply *forget* about price. It's better that way, you can just relax and soak it in, and you have no need for guilt later. With that caveat out of the way...  Reservations were made, we received a follow-up call on day of dinner to confirm and remind of no young children policy unless in a private room. Yay! Thanks! (seriously) This is an adult experience and a sublime atmosphere and I relished that opportunity to reduce one potential risk of spoiling it.  We showed up on time, were greeted professionally and shown to our table which was very comfortable and private. The restaurant is arranged to facilitate privacy and intimacy with generous table spacing and differing levels. There are what appear at first glance to be framed mirrored panels between booths but are in fact clear glass panels. It's an optical illusion and aside from visual aesthetics, served to insulate and block sound from adjacent booths. Great design!  The atmosphere in general is low-key, dimly-lit and very sexy. Very conducive to big-dollar deals, romance, or just peaceful and relaxing! :-D  All this was great, however what quickly became apparent and carried through to the end of the night there was the service! Amazing! I just do not see how it could have been better. Water was topped off, used utensils and settings whisked away and quickly replaced, sommelier visits, and the "main person", I hate to call him a "waiter", let's say instead our "Evening Experience Manager" - Danny, was always on top of things. Top to bottom, front to back, absolutely perfect dining experience.  In fact, in a very fortunate life of varied dining experiences, I feel comfortable to call this this The Best Service We Have Ever Had In Any Restaurant Anywhere. So there it is.  The cocktails were delicious, I had a lychee martini, three actually, and they were superb. There is an extensive and well-curated wine and liquor list, some bottles extending deep into five-figures for those seeking a heroic end of night tab.    The food was very good and very artfully presented. The spot shrimp presentation was simply a work of art, and I won't post a picture so as not to ruin the surprise! I struggle a bit to describe the flavors and will settle on this - the food was respected and not overpowered with heavy seasoning and sauces. Some would instead call it plain or simple or under-seasoned. My suggestion to the reader is it takes courage to prepare fresh, unique ingredients with a light hand and to allow the natural (light, clean) flavors to shine through. If you like a heavy hand on flavorings, this will not be your favorite experience.    The dessert was, again, very well executed with a light hand and clean flavors.  I want to say thank you again to all who contributed to our dining experience at Blossom! Your attention to detail is and was appreciated! We'll be back for sure, there is a lot to try on the menu and we just scratched the surface.

vNR46gENiZ9mr4w_PvTs8A.text: We had a great time last night! The restaurant it's gorgeous and we really like the ambiance. The service also was excellent but we had no idea who was the main server since we had help from everyone. I do recommend the macadamia chicken breast. It's unbelievable how the macadamia stays crispy on the sauce. The Cream Brulee it's a delicious surprise chocolate ball. The coconut rice texture and flavor was to die.

OYAW4pb2_yeiCuZfcJ4C1A.text: This restaurant is located inside the Aria.  All items on the menu were at least $20 even fried rice but we pay for the great service / good meal. We wanted to try the good Chinese food but I'd go to China town next time cause they are cheaper.

CE4YY7lMP8-22XBJ9ewDdQ.text: The BBQ pork here is so good, it made me want to punch somebody. There's something here for all tastes and price points - for around $100, we had two entrees, two appetizers, and one amazing mojito. There are some more authentically Chinese dishes, but as fans of American Chinese takeout, it was fun to try the premium versions of our favorite lazy weeknight dishes. The walnut shrimp is out if this world - delicious fried shrimp on a bed of melon and candied walnuts, with mayo drizzled over. Sounds weird, but comes together beautifully. The shiitake mushroom appetizer was surprisingly tasty, but was swiftly overshadowed by the aforementioned pork. The kung pao chicken was perfection. I can't wait to come back and try the Peking duck - the table next to us ordered it and it smelled incredible.  The decor is lovely and the space is well-arranged. The service is without fault - attentive but unobtrusive, no waiting for refills or plates to be cleared. Fantastic meal!

Mm6k-YtG-nnh_KTxdralOw.text: I was a bit skeptical in trying this restaurant as to the other Chinese restaurant that's located at Wynn. This restaurant is located at the Aria. We had reservations and were seated promptly. I had very good impression regarding the wait staff. They were very efficient without being too intrusive. Waters were filled promptly. The sommelier came to take our wine orders. We instructed our waitress that we wanted the dishes to come at the same time since we wanted it "family style" dining. First came the duck. The duck took two wait staff to slice and put in sio pao buns. This particular duck was the highlight of our trip. It's one of the best Peking ducks I have ever tasted. It was succulent and moist. I would go back to this restaurant and just have the duck. We also had the flounder dish. This particular dish was a standout as well. I vividly remember the Peking duck and flounder dishes. My benchmark for an enjoyable meal are the unforgettable dishes and these two hit the spot. Together with exemplary service. We felt very pampered at this particular meal. I would go back to this restaurant again.

3kzvzyvZd75r7lI4jCbCtg.text: Simply the best Chinese restaurant in Vegas! The wait staff is so attentive and helpful! The food is exceptional. A few of my favorites....crispy rolls with beef and mushroom; e-fu noodles with scallops; kung pao chicken. You can't go wrong with anything on their menu! Enjoy!

NvROZRhKI7IEzu1_6Vj6DQ.text: There is a final scene in Ratatouille when Anton Ego bites into a rustic peasant dish of ratatouille and drops his pen, amazed by the haunting replication of his mother's country cooking.  That would be me eating hom yu ji yuk bang at Blossom.   For the uninitiated, this is a rustic peasant Chinese dish of ground pork cake with salted fish.  It is an easy dish to make, but a difficult dish to make well.  The smell of this dish is akin to an Asian smelling blue cheese for the first time.  My wife smiled at me slyly anticipating some anguished white nose whiffs as the dish travels through the restaurant.  Who would ever order that here, she asked, how fresh can the salted fish be? When I bit into the dish, I slowly dropped my chopsticks to mimic Anton Ego.  This shit is good--the salted fish was tender, flaky,  and flavorful and the ground pork had a sweet salty taste that has the addictive allure of high quality spam--and I don't mean that in a bad way!  The walnut shrimp was almost perfect--it was just slightly overdone as the shrimp was not at its peak juicy, but the batter was light, the shrimp was jumbo, and the mayo was light.  It was served on a bed of cantaloupe and honeydew.  The dish had terrific textures of crunchy, slippery, hot and cold.  The lil guy's chicken soup had a clean sweetish broth taste that came from long-simmering chicken.  The only disappointment was with the stir-fried filet mignon.  The sauce was flavorful and peppery, but the texture was off.  It tasted a little like it had been in the freezer a little too long; the beef had a slightly mushy, dryish feel to it that did not seem right.  This was a surprise for us because it is precisely the kind of dish that would be popular here with non-Chinese, so the beef should be fresh due to turnover.  There was no wok hei(flavor that comes from the wok) in this dish.  The service was unparalleled.  I don't think I've had better service in a Chinese restaurant.  When they brought the sweet and sour soup for the lil guy, the waitress caught his crinkled expression and offered immediately to replace the spicy soup with something else.  When the lil guy expressed a wish for noodles in his chicken soup, the kitchen quietly made an off-menu dish for him.  When we had the hom yu boxed, the server offered another bowl of rice, as he knew this salty protein required a balancing carb.  Service was efficient, unintrusive, and friendly.  About half the customers were Asian, with Cantonese being spoken pretty freely.    Prices are high, ranging in the 20s to 40s, with rarer dishes upwards of $100-300, but still extremely reasonable compared to other such restaurants:  a dinner at Jean Georges or Bardot next door is easily twice the price.  It takes a particular skill to cook good Chinese food that is different from say putting a seasoned steak in a broiler.  Decor was beautifully tasteful.  I will definitely return to try other dishes, but the hom yu will be a staple for me at this restaurant!

Stv_8Ht95gbZrav02ceElw.text: Great service, one of the best Chinese restaurant in town. All the food is great except the beef dish, a little over cooked. Just made another reservation to try their seafood dish.

fc5GD7gqVcA7MN1lzFEu2Q.text: Had a hankering for peking duck and searched restaurants along the strip for the best place. While yelp stars for Blossom wasn't the highest, I still selected Blossom based on the treatment of the duck. I was looking for table side carving with lots of crispy skin served with steamed buns. And while Blossom did this well, they also took the rest of the duck back to be chopped up as a duck entree. This was okay, but I was hoping for a larger serving Peking duck style with buns/wraps than just regular duck to eat with rice. We actually got our Peking duck served with both buns and wraps - the sauce was tasty and the cucumber/onions were fresh and crunchy. It was yummy and reminded me of similar experiences eating Peking duck in Bejing.  In addition to the duck, we had the hot and sour soup (spicy and tangy, one of the better hot and sour soups out there) and sauteed pea shoots (simple yet executed perfectly).   For drinks, I tried the Blossom cocktail, which consisted of a ginger/lemongrass infused soju, rock sugar, and was served with a Thai bird chili. It was very flavorful and I wish I remembered the rest of the ingredients! Definitely give it a try.  All in all, Blossom was fine dining at its best. Go for the experience. You won't be disappointed.

9UzWF5G3LQxUqtavdZVy2w.text: Excellent food and really really good service all the way around.  Manager went out of his way to accomodate me.

gr-tUrHwdu3UiSJyPHZO0A.text: Came here about 1 hour before they were closing with the husband, place was packed so had to wait a few minutes, but glad we did!   Ambiance - Place is dark, has a nice seating and set up and if you sit in the back area table or booths, it is a more romantic feeling than the middle section where there are larger tables for big groups.   Food - We were so lost! This was actually our first time to a "Real" Cantonese food place thingy. One of the ladies working there was kind enough to take a few minutes and go over the menu and point out favorites and ask about our tastes and after a few questions we made our order!  We chose to share two entrees, an appetizer and a fried rice. The portions were HUGE! Since we had never been here, we assumed fancy place, tiny portions, which is why we ordered so much, but next time, one entree would be more than enough for two people with a side of their awesome rice.   BBQ Pork -  This is made by an in house specialty bbq chef and it shows! When I first ordered it, I had the mindset of bbq pork from a normal Chinese take away restaurant, and wow I am glad I was wrong! This was so tender, juicy and just a little bit of the bbq sauce. It was perfection! No fat on the meat and none of that weird taste, I could barely tell it was pork.   Garlic Prawn Fried rice - Holy Prawn batman! These things were HUGE. I thought it would be a small portion of rice, but it came in this enormous bowl with at least 10 HUGE shrimp .. did I mention they were huge? More than enough for two people to share!   Chilean Sea bass -  This was so good, it was just ridiculous at this point. The outside was crispy and crunchy, perfection and the inside was juicy and melt in your mouth delicious. I wondered how on earth they were able to keep the inside So wet while the outside was crispy, but who cares, my taste buds didnt ask just questions, they just enjoyed.   Kung Pao shrimp - Not your favorite take aways kung pao, but like a billion times better. The shrimp were huge again, juicy succulent awesome shrimp. You know the shrimp you see on television commercials that just look so big and awesome but then you get sad little stuff at the actual place? Well these bad boys were the ones from the commercial, but better?!   10/10 ... would eat there again and again and probably another time just for safe measure.

DLwVREW6eOwpp4iPs6W_ow.text: Very nice place to go. The wait staff was amazing. Very friendly and as we were celebrating our anniversary this weekend, they were very accommodating and helped us celebrate.   We ordered the tempura string beans to start. Very good. Perfectly cooked. Not to much batter which means you get more of the string bean taste. I was sort of hoping for a more of an aioli type sauce to go with it, but it was like a soy sauce type of mixture. Good but I wanted a more of a dipping sauce.   We ordered the Lemon Chicken, Mongolian Beef and Vegetable Chow Mein. Highly recommend the Mongolian Beef. That was delicious!!! The chow Mein was good as well. The Lemon Chicken was just okay. Nothing bad, nothing fantastic either.   The gave us mochi balls for dessert for free which was quite lovely.

yACzmL7eZ-_nrVCqIy_rCQ.text: A Chinese restaurant in Vegas? There's no way they would ever be able to make authentic Chinese food.. WRONG!!  I was fortunate to be able to dine at Blossom many times during my stay at Aria, all of which were complimentary. Though I did notice that food could be on the pricey end, it's totally worth it! Their food is as authentic as it could get and I enjoyed it! The servers were very attentive and the decor of the place is amazing.  - Hot and sour soup was very tasty and just right. - Won ton soup was also delicious!  - We ordered both the maine lobster and dungeness crab, steamed with scallion broth. Of the two, I like the dungeness crab better! - Peking duck was superb with the buns! - Chow mein and vegetable fried rice were also very delicious. I prefer the chow mein though. - Kung pao chicken has just the right flavors. - Beef broccoli is something you can't go wrong with.  Worth a trip here!

a5LyqWz18lAhYYLI0SSYNQ.text: Great place for authentic Chinese food. The servers were very attentive. They kept our drinks full. The atmosphere was traditional formal. We started with vegetable egg rolls with fresh vegetables inside. We also had pot stickers that were the best I have ever had. The waitress suggested mandarin pork and offered to substitute with chicken. The Schezwan shrimp was spicy with good heat and my husband enjoyed every last bite he even ate the sauce with the leftover rice.  The garlic prawn fried rice was very flavorful. The portions were just right. The meal was complete with a gift box of tea leaves and pineapple bread. Will defiantly return on my next visit to Vegas.

fbxxOqbK1VimPLMTtbUTfQ.text: We made a reservation to come her for our anniversary dinner. The atmosphere is excellent, but the food is so bland. I kept telling my husband I would have picked Panda Express over this. Kung Pao chicken claims to be "medium spicy", but there was literally zero spice. Also, they acknowledged that it was our anniversary and didn't do A THING to make us feel special, so don't expect that if you're going for yours.

NuWqbVLfTFUa7zLdYO8iRg.text: Should be 10 stars. This place spoiled us rotten. We came here for our 2 year anniversary and everything was perfect. The service was flawless (huge thanks to Lily, Owen and Allen); they were professional, attentive & super nice. The food took it to the next level. We got the Peking Duck (see photo) and yeah, it cost a Benjamin, but my God. The taste was absolutely breathtaking. They carve it up at your table and serve it to you in the buns and then come back later to give you the rest of it. They then gave us mochi ice cream, sesame balls and mini box with tea & a pineapple cookie all on the house.  Go. Go now.

UXxFYlTAK9vxn-GiJyifHA.text: July 26, 2019 - Blossoms Location: Aria Hotel Casino level.    Are you in Vegas and craving authentic Chinese food and Peking duck, Peking duck, Peking Duck?    This place is a wonderful place to impress a date or your wife of 16 years.   We dressed up just to set the mood this time but have dined here previously wearing casual clothes as well.      The duck is always crispy and meat is moist.   Duck is always greasy but at Blossoms it is minimal.  The duck is brought in a cart and professionally carved and served table side.  As an option remaining meat can be prepared with fried rice.    The Peking Duck yields 8 buns filled with shredded green onion and cucumbers.  The duck fried rice and beef chow fun  noodles were delicious but we had to take most of it to go.    5 star service from the hostess, our waiters and our Peking Duck carver.  Cons: Open only till 11pm

A4QVM4I8gu6mE9SS7zUoJw.text: Blossom is a Chinese restaurant in the Aria, and it's notable for a couple of reasons. One is that it's one of the most expensive Chinese restaurants I've ever visited. The other is that the food is truly delicious.  Matt B. and I went for a Friday dinner at the end of May with my brother Andrew C. and his girlfriend Celestine H., who had been to Blossom a few times before. We were able to make an 8:30 reservation just a couple hours in advance, after arriving in Vegas on an early evening flight. The dining room--opulent and high-ceilinged, decked out in clubby chinoiserie--felt quiet for a Friday night. I'm having a hard time picturing other guests in the restaurant, though it's possible the tables were just really spaced out. They were huge tables--we were seated at what must have been a table for four, but it felt like we were all very far away from each other.  Service was solid, polite and professional, almost formal, with wait staff in suits carving Peking duck and dropping plate after plate of food on our table. The one hitch was that the drinks were slow in coming, arriving well after our food started to arrive. The drinks were the weak part of our dinner at Blossom overall. We ordered cocktails, and they were pretty sweet across the board. I got the Mango Chili-Lime, which was my favorite of the bunch, with Tequila Ocho Plata, pineapple, mango, lime, and Tajin. Matt had the Time After Thyme, a whiskey drink with Suntory Toki, Creme de Cassis, lemon, and thyme; not bad, but nothing special. Andrew and Celestine had the Cherry Blossom--Grey Goose La Poire, lychee, Lillet, and cherry--and the Mandarin Orange--Hangar One Mandarin, watermelon, cucumber, and lime--neither of them very good.  The food was great, though, surprisingly so for a Chinese restaurant on a casino floor. The menu was massive and varied--we ordered what we thought was a lot of food and missed several whole categories. As it turned out, I was glad we got everything we did, both because it was tasty and because the portions weren't nearly as big as I thought they'd be. No bounty of leftovers from Blossom.  We started with the BBQ ribs and the BBQ pork, and both of these were superb. The ribs were wonderfully tender, fatty and slipping off the bone, lacquered with a sweet and savory glaze. I took pride in gnawing mine clean. The BBQ pork--I think this was char siu--was meaty and flavorful, served in thin slices. Both the ribs and the char siu came garnished simply with sprigs of cilantro, and I enjoyed them with the two sauces on the table--hot chili sauce and soy sauce swimming with jalapeno and red pepper.  We shared the Peking duck, and this became the centerpiece of our dinner. Our servers carved up the roast duck by our table, then prepared individual buns and wraps with duck, scallion, and plum sauce. They presented these to us neatly plated. We were offered a choice of steamed buns or wraps, and I got one of each. The duck was excellent--crispy skin, succulent meat, just right with the scallions and plum sauce and pillowy bun and thin Chinese pancake. I was disappointed, though, that we only got two buns or wraps each, as there was plenty of meat left, and I would've liked to make more of them. Instead, we got the leftover meat in a big heap with a side of sweet and sour sauce. This was great, too, but I missed the ritual aspect of the traditional Peking duck meal. (To be fair, this might only be because I took Chinese in college, and we spent like a whole month learning all the vocabulary around eating Peking duck--or as I forever remember it, Beijing kaoya.)  We rounded out our dinner with string beans, ma po tofu, and garlic prawn fried rice. The string beans were good, if not especially memorable, with a spicy XO meat sauce that could have been spicier. The ma po tofu was the most mediocre dish we ordered, not bad, but pretty bland. That fried rice, though, was fantastic--fluffy and flavorful, not shy with the garlic, with a decent number of plump, snappy, sweet prawns.  I wasn't expecting to find such impressive Chinese food on the Strip, and I'm not even mad that it cost twice as much as good Chinese food at home in L.A. (maybe four times as much, if you account for portion size). Not everything was amazing--and certainly the cocktails should've been better--but I loved the ribs and the pork, the duck and the fried rice. I'd be curious to try the crab sometime, though that's even more of a splurge. In any case, I expect I'll eat at Blossom again. I love Vegas and I love Chinese food, and now that I know about this place, I'll definitely want to come back.

CnuXgyEnf-mLS2giNZb_4g.text: Enjoyed a delicious meal at Blossom.  Great food and wonderful ambiance.   Had the Shrimp Toast, BBQ pork. Mongolian Beef, and Braised tofu and Mushrooms.  Service was fantastic!

hvGVshZOHSmieX4Okzq51A.text: Delicious but pricey Chinese food (but hey, what else do you expect in Vegas?)  The restaurant is located in ARIA. We had a bit of a hard time finding it since there weren't any signs and it wasn't in the lobby area, but we asked around and was directed to walk through the casino from the lobby, and it was on the right once we walked far enough.  My friend had made a reservation beforehand for Sunday dinner at 7 pm. I'd definitely recommend a reservation, as it was pretty empty when we first arrived but was mostly filled out by the time we left around 8:30.  A couple of us ordered cocktails, which were $16. I went with the mandarin orange, which was vodka based and had a lovely watermelon flavor. I tried a sip of my friend's mango chili-lime and the matcha spice, but the mandarin orange was by far my favorite if you like fruity flavors like me.  For food we ordered:  Steamed sea bass ($42): the sea bass was served on top of tofu. The sea bass was really fresh, but the main flavor came from the black bean sauce sprinkled on top, which didn't have quite enough flavor to cover the whole dish. Portions were also really small for the price  Spicy veal cheek ($35): it's not actually that spicy, which is a lot coming from me since I have zero spice tolerance. The meat was flavorful and tender. My second favorite dish of the night  Garlic prawn fried rice ($20): this was really good! Favorite dish of the whole table  Pan fried pea shoots ($25): solid veggie dish, but again, I couldn't believe how much we were paying for this dish  Service was solid, as you would expect from a high end place like this.  It was ~$60 pp for dinner + one cocktail.

k8iGUrP2d8rUEWY45Tklzg.text: If you've ever driven or walked down The Strip,  you've probably seen an appealing jumbo-tron image of a whole crispy crab, laying atop a white plate. Well, that beautiful crab is one of the signature dishes at Blossom. My love and I were excited to meet some friends at Blossom, but come early for the crab, because on this visit, it was sold out! Meaning, we'll be back again with an earlier reservation!  When you walk through the entrance, the airy, yet well spaced out, dining room captures your eyes. It is quite an elegant space they've created with a beautiful, semi- translucent, white wall and an Asian inspired wooden door.   The menu is substantial, but not too overwhelming...Appetizers, Seafood, Meat and of course the Peking Duck! I'm not a big fan of duck since it is too greasy for my taste, but here at Blossom, it was crispy, tender and without so much of the greasiness that generally turns me off. In addition to the incredible duck, we also shared Steamed Seabass, crispy Calamari, Filet Mignon with Egg Plant, Seafood Rice Noodles, and Ochoi.    The staff was effortlessly moving from table to table, satisfying our needs and more, and all without any interruption. It was a delightful meal and a beautiful evening!  -2019 review #2-

FQiyVvyG_p4qzDkyy5PSXw.text: Blossom was spectacular!   FOOD The food here is delicious! The tempura green beans was my absolute favorite! The entire table could not stop eating them.  The shrimp lettuce cups were a solid choice as well. I would also highly recommend the hot and sour soup. It's super flavorful and full of spice. If you're not that into spices, the tofu + mushroom soup is also really good. It's the perfect comfort soup.   DRINKS I loved the drinks here. The cocktails are a bit dangerous because they taste soooo good!  ATMOSPHERE/SERVICE They told us to dress business casual -- but I'd say it's more business than casual. The place is quite fancy and the service was spectacular. Everyone was so kind and really took their time to take care of us. We had a vegan in our party and they brought out a vegan menu for her. They were also able to adjust dishes to accommodate her. Definitely vegan/vegetarian friendly!   Overall -- if I were rich, I'd eat here all the time!

photos.caption: Photo of Blossom - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp lettuce wraps + string bean tempura

GlIipn1zv1-Tgb8ak4cEeQ.text: It was back to Blossom with friends for high-end, refined Chinese cuisine.  After we settled into a comfortable and opulent booth, this time I began with an interesting Amuse Bouche of spinach, garlic & ginger, along with a pot of Jasmine Pearls Tea for me, and a pot of Silver Needle Chrysanthemum Tea for Diane.  An array of starters included a Crisp-Fried Beef Roll with Enoki Mushrooms & Mandarin Brown Sauce, Pan-fried Pork Pot Stickers, and Vegetable Egg Rolls.  All were delectable.    While Diane enjoyed an individual serving of Wor Wonton Soup with Shrimp & Scallops, I delighted in a double serving of excellent spicy Hot & Sour Soup.  After finishing off the apps and soup course, we settled in with eager anticipation while awaiting the arrival of our ordered entrees.    I paired my main of Beef Tenderloin & Black Mushrooms in Black Pepper Sauce with Shrimp Fried Rice that had very small grains.  Steamed Stuffed Shrimp and Walnut Prawns went to fellow diners.    Service by Tony K. and others was nonstop.  I asked for Soy Sauce, Hoisin Sauce, Hot Chinese Chili Oil, and ginger, and received all of them plus Jalapenos in Soy Sauce and XO Sauce!  Though I hardly needed more food, to complete the meal I ordered the Ice Cream Trio: Taro Ice Cream, Mandarin-Yuzu Sorbet, and Chocolate Ice Cream served with a handmade Fortune Cookie.  Complimentary Sesame Cookies and a giant Fortune Cookie without a fortune inside rounded out our Cantonese feast  They were fresh and tasty.  Since its appearance, the empty Fortune Cookie has not resulted in any noticeable bad luck for me.  So I plan to return--a lot sooner than last time.

9dzTqhX0ApsIpGrrJFAqUA.text: Walking into blossom, it looks like a fancy MGM property restaurant. No views here, just nice contemporary meets Asian decor.  To start, we did the fried ice fish appetizer and fried calamari both were a but flavorless and greasy. The goose liver was good, it was a nice take on a Chinese styled foie gras. The poached live prawns were good, but kinda small. Fried rice, Singapore noodles, XO string beans, and eggplant clay pot we're about the same quality that you would get in Chinatown here at a quarter of the price.   We ended the entrees with a 4 pound live coral cod. At $100 a pound, it was as expected... Super tender and incredibly delicious.   Service was good, but a little bit clumsy. The sauce platter was placed on someone's phone, and the servers spilled 2 glasses of water at our table. They recommended the prawns poached then later when bringing the check they told us the prawns are so much better a different way. So that was a little confusing and annoying  It's a Chinese restaurant at an MGM property. Similar ingredients and similar menu to Jasmine at the Bellagio, but if you are spending this kind of money on Chinese food... Jasmine is much better.

bHLBbWz4Tuo46JjPneIexw.text: Upon walking into this establishment there is no mistaking that blossom is high end fine dining. The restaurant was over staffed, but the staff seemed clumsy and awkward. They were constantly spilling stuff on our table. By my count, they spilled dipping sauces twice on the white table cloth and water three times. By the end of our meal, I had hot tea spilled all over my arms and my fancy nye dress and our table cloth had a layer of extra cloth napkins over it... it looked sloppy and unprofessional at best.   For appetizers we had:  1. fried fish - super oily and too much batter 2. fried calamari - super oily and too much batter  3. Goose liver - very good  For entrees we had: 1. Singapore noodles - good 2. Santa Barbara prawns - they were good, but shrimp sized 3. Lobster fried rice - good 4. String bean xo - good 5. Coral cod - took forever, so by the time it came out we were full already and didn't really enjoy it as much  For dessert: 1. Mango pomelo cold soup: very refreshing in a weird way because i first saw it I almost thought some one throw up in this bowl of dessert , for real !  Ps : so when we were ordering food, the server David highly recommended having the prawns poached. Then when he was bringing the check he said we needed to get them cooked with garlic over noodles... we asked why he didn't recommend that at first and his only response was, " because I want you guys to come back tomorrow." Smh

joKPMzGmMIMOMnl-b0I97g.text: Blown away I was by Blossom's elegant aura, extensive Cantonese menu, and, impressive wine list.  Efficient was the service even with many huge celebratory tables in hand on this Saturday night.  A show stopper was their steamed "Santa Barbara Spot Prawns"; perfectly executed, so sweet and tender.  Another gem was their "Steam Salted Fish with Ground Pork", wow, comfort food at its best.    Being that this is a fine dining restaurant, I expected their desserts to match with their fabulous savory dishes.  Not so though, for I'd skip their blase "coconut rice pudding"  in the future.  CHEERS!
